title: Implement signal quality vs speed correlation analysis
description:
Create analysis proving network congestion, not signal issues:

## Key Analysis Needed
1. **Signal Quality Assessment**
   - Show average RSRP is in acceptable range (-90 to -100 dBm = fair)
   - Show average SINR is acceptable (10-20 dB = good)
   - Prove signal quality is NOT the issue

2. **Speed vs Signal Correlation**
   - Scatter plots: speed vs SINR, speed vs RSRP
   - Show that even with GOOD signal, speeds are still <10 Mbps
   - This proves congestion/deprioritization, not signal issue

3. **Time Pattern Analysis**  
   - Show 2am speeds of 150 Mbps with same signal quality
   - Compare daytime vs nighttime with same tower/signal
   - Proves tower capacity/congestion issue

## Conclusion to Demonstrate
'Signal quality is acceptable (SINR: X dB, RSRP: X dBm) but speeds remain below 10 Mbps, indicating network congestion or QoS deprioritization rather than a coverage issue'

title: Create FCC informal complaint submission guide
description:
Document process and prepare for FCC complaint submission:

## FCC Consumer Complaint Process
1. **Informal Complaint** (recommended first)
   - Submit at: https://consumercomplaints.fcc.gov
   - Category: Internet
   - Sub-category: Speed/Service Quality
   - Company required to respond within 30 days

2. **Required Information**
   - Account holder name and contact
   - T-Mobile account number
   - Service address
   - Plan name and cost
   - Description of issue
   - What resolution you want

3. **Supporting Evidence to Attach**
   - Speed test history (CSV/PDF)
   - Signal metrics report
   - Support interaction log
   - Screenshots of advertised speeds
   - Correlation analysis

## Complaint Narrative Template
'I have been a T-Mobile Home Internet subscriber since [date], paying [amount]/month for service advertised at 133-415 Mbps download. For the past 3 months, my actual speeds have consistently been below 10 Mbps (less than 7.5% of minimum advertised) at all hours except approximately 2am. 

Signal quality metrics from my gateway show acceptable levels (SINR: X dB, RSRP: X dBm), indicating this is not a coverage issue but rather network congestion or deliberate deprioritization.

When I contacted T-Mobile support, I was told that speed tests don't matter if I can watch YouTube videos. I have documented X speed tests over Y days showing consistent underperformance.

I am seeking: [refund/credit/service improvement/release from contract without penalty]'
